xdnK2cL5iDwyWvdDdMWLRg.text: Scrumdiddlyumptious. Thought I'd cut to the chase. Conveniently for me, this is about a 30 second walk from my house, however, I would walk at least 100 times that if I had to. Situated in 'Little Hanoi' on Kingsland road, there is nothing remarkable about it form the outside. Upon entering, the lovely, lovely waiting staff seat you whether you are waiting for a table or for take-away. All smiles and consideration, they bring you a generous portion of prawn crackers. Perusing through the bamboo covered, sensibly laminated, menu is a joy and a chore. Joyous because the food all sounds wonderful and a chore because narrowing it down sometimes proves impossible! Once you have managed to reduce the items to a shortlist (I'd recommend the grilled beef with lemongrass) the price is very reasonable at around £5 for a main with £2 or so for rice, depending on your choice. A 'Bring your own Booze' policy also keeps costs down. All fresh, good quality ingredients, fantastic flavours, authentic, friendly atmosphere and very reasonably priced - you can see why this is one of my favourite places to eat!

photos.caption: Photo of Mien Tay - London, United Kingdom

hcW0Zny4wWXC_eXUMnZfpA.text: SCORE!!!!!!!11111111111111  Good pho in London, found.  I know there is a huge Song Que/Viet Grill following, but this place has it down, solid.  The broth flavor, combined with ALL the fixins (LIME!!!) and the correct sriracha hot sauce.  Money...so, so money.I wish I could teleport to this place every Saturday morning, since the prawn and pork spring rolls and the mung bean pancake are the best thing to cure whatever remnants of mischief you got up to after work on Friday.  And then zap back again on Sunday afternoonish as well...Hoorah!!  Let's keep the quality HIGH at this place cuz we know yelp's gonna make the quantity of clientele explode to ridiculous levels.  Mien Tay is blowing upppp!

_xdy_p1iQ4i9X9NYE-PeVQ.text: If you look for a quiet place for a romantic evening, that's probably not the best place to go. It's packed (be prepared to share a table with strangers in much closer vicinity than in Wagamama), it's laud, there are people queuing to get tables staring enviously into your plates. But once you get your food, you immediately forget about everything! The food is absolutely fantastic! The portions are massive (also the starters), and considering the crowd, we didn't have to wait very long. I take one star for the service. Mine and my boyfriend's starters arrived about 10 minutes apart. They didn't bring the drinks we ordered and when we asked for them they said they lost the order and they don't know what to bring. The service was a bit chaotic, but that's probably what happens when you have 5 different people serve the same table. The nice thing is that you can bring your own bottle of wine. And don't forget to book a table, otherwise you'll have to queue for 40 minutes to get one.

sifQpT68fTKamSiqK9SHMA.text: My companion and I had a lunch at this place today. we initially tried to order from their lunch special menu, but we were told by the waitress that it wasn't applicable on Sundays.  The menu didn't specify which days of the week it offered the "lunch menu".  So we ordered from the regular menu: shrimp and pork fresh roll wand, 2 grilled pork bun vermicelli dishes.  Shortly after taking our order, we were given complimentary shrimp crackers.  It was nothing special just plain old crunchy shrimp crackers. Our fresh shrimp and pork rolls arrive 10 minutes later, 2 pieces of spring roll with hoisin & peanut sauce. Small portion for the price but it was good, fresh ingredients. The bun vermicelli dishes arrive 10 minutes later.  The first thing we noticed was the portions were very small.  The pickled cucumbers and carrots which help make this dish were practically nonexistent.  Although on the upside, the fried pork spring rolls that came with the dish was very good!  It was presented slightly differently, rather than coming wrapped in looked to have a fluffy battered coating, almost like a tempura. It was delicious!  The grilled pork was also well flavoured, but again the dish could have used a slightly larger portion of meat.  Overall, the food was good but for the price that I was paying I was expecting a slightly larger portion.

P0Ir_M9Xq6VvlAlHURxJXw.text: Four and a half if not for the stink. Oh well what to expect from Asian restaurants that has poor ventilation and pungent food. (pungent in a good way FYI).food is good, reminds my good old pho days in the US; paired with the great sriracha reminds me of my freezing cold college days. Have not had good pho lately but since reviews says its good, so off I go to fulfill my cravings and hunger while visiting this beautiful town!piece of advice, if you want to get the fish sauce, tell them the soy sauce kind, not the mixed up kind (has vinegar, sugar, chilli variation, don't really like it but it does the trick). I'd say a must visit, this place!!

92o4wATkdkVl0hJcIIUwow.text: Best pho I've had in London so far! Coming from California, London's pho has been largely disappointing so far, but this place was quite outstanding, highly recommend! great service as well!

nWwgEDEkjdGHWi9CZQH3uQ.text: My favourite vietnamise on kingsland road. Would recomend the salt and pepper garlic squid and the vermincelli chargrilled goat.

hzcDgC4WJTFy1P01LuHxqQ.text: I had this one in the drafts for quite a while...I visited Mien Tay on a Monday night so the place was fairly quiet. Despite being half empty it still took quite a while for the staff to get our order and for the food to arrive. Nothing too bad...... except...... it sucks to wait when your table is in close proximity to a door that leads straight to the street. It was a particularly cold evening so every time someone opened the door you would get the occasional glacier breeze. The place feels like a family business that hasn't change since the seventies (and there's nothing wring with that). There's always this background music that could be taken out of a half empty shopping mall - think Hotel California, the polyphonic version.Ambiance covered, onto food!The spring rolls were nice and so was the pork with egg and rice, but what really shined was the pancakes. OMG. Call off the search for delicious food, your prodigal son has returned! It's the kind of stuff you wish someone had introduced in your life when you were 10 years old. Try them and you will know exactly what I mean.So all in all, it's not the most amazing place in the world but it's not bad either. I give it a 3 and a ;) but wouldn't mind coming back for more of those pancakes!

aWBmUCmbHAwB0JqzTZ_pZg.text: One of my favorite places in London.I'll be honest: the quality of the meat in the pho varies quite a bit, but everything else is totally spot on. I have absolutely wonderful memories of sitting by the window with a bottle of wine (BYO), a cute boy, and a steaming bowl of noodles with fresh herbs and spicy tofu. Definitely one of the best ways to spend 10 quid.

iDqyAW6A-CX9dmontCUF2Q.text: If you're after some decent pho and wanting a quick meal...this is the place to be. Free prawn crackers whilst you have a good look through the menu. They do a yummy stir-fry morning glory veggie dish and gorgeous freshly made spring rolls. Pretty good value for money. Don't expect a lot from table service or staff interaction though.

ZsiC6k6FZSbM6TRsxfH-3Q.text: My new favourite Kingslander for three reasons:1. Food - huge good Pho but also lots of variety too with hard-to-find dishes like spicy Mekong catfish soup. The free crackers and goodbye orange are wicked good too.2. Value - two people left as giant warm tasty spherical balls of goodness for £143. Atmosphere - dinner at Rainforest Cafe will cost you your hearing, sanity and your wallet but Mien Tay are doing their best to offer you the same jungle feeling without the hassle. The wonderfully kitsch decor is topped by the plastic palm trees with animatronic tweeting birds of paradise. The owner lady takes real pride in her collection of made-in-Shenzhen bric-a-brac. Rightly so. It's great fun.Make sure to check out their Buddha shrine - seems he has a drinking habit.

photos.caption: Photo of Mien Tay - London, United Kingdom. Mekong catfish spicy soup and a huge Pho Dac Biet

uA0258PsBzy_uy6qOqEAGw.text: Mien Tay is the sort of restaurant I'll only go into with a recommendation.  Call me superficial, but it's just a little bit grubby.  Ok, it's not exactly a SE Asian shophouse restaurant, but it could do with a refurb.  But once I'm there, I'm happy if the food's good.  We went with a banh xeo for starter (happy crispy pancake) - it passed the main test in that it was nice and crispy.  For mains, I went with pho whilst my friend enjoyed his catfish.  The pho had a nice flavour, although I was a little dismayed about 45 minutes later when I started to get MSG mouth.  To be honest, the soup really didn't need it so it seemed a little unnecessary.  Ok, it's kind of my fault for insisting on finishing every last drop of broth at every restaurant I go to, but I'm just not a big fan of the stuff (feelings of extreme thirst and hunger after big meals).Overall, it's a pretty solid eatery and the staff are very pleasant.  I'd be keen to try some of their other stuff sometime.

8qrTpsYMR15NMmfK38q4TQ.text: Recommended by a friend of mine VERY demanding with Vietnamese food after living there for several years. AMAZINGReally good experience, staff and food. Note: if you are dessert lovers, not the right place to go to though ;)Great: Pork meatballs with honey and spices.

ko8k4g4EInIbNxvSgkGnSQ.text: Scene: Birthday party  dinner at Mien TayKey actors: A birthday Yelper and about 5 subsidiary Yelpers, plus a couple newbies.Snippets of the conversations from the night:Excuse me....sir, Excuse me? Um, can we order now? Hello?**20 minutes later**Yes, I'll have the number 134. No...no, not the 27, the 134. ONE.THREE.FOUR. That one by my finger. No....YES, that one!**20 minutes later**Um, excuse me? we haven't received our bottle of Prosecco....Prosecco. Sparkling Wine. NUMBER 21!Basically, the service is what did it in. It took forever to get our food, they misunderstood half of our order and at the end of the night, they actually had the audacity to pick up my friend's coat and bag as he pushed his chair out and basically pushed him out the door thirty minutes before we were supposed to be gone from our pre-booked table.Yes, the food was very good, but seriously? Going to have to step it up a notch, guys.

H2PkcMyF9H6mJHmMHpKcXA.text: This family run Vietnamese on Kingland Road in Shoreditch already has a solid reputation and loyal following (including me). It specialises in cuisine from South Vietnam and serves a wonderful array of dishes including the amazing Char Grilled Quail with Honey, Garlic & Spices and the Prawn and Green Papaya Salad both of which I order every time I go. What makes this restaurant stand out on Kingland Road's 'pho mile' is the lively atmosphere and quality of food, service and the value for money. It's also BYO which is a bonus. I discovered Miey Tay after it was mentioned on Gordon Ramsey's Best Restaurant and am very happy that I did. It is however a strangely well kept secret that I am more than happy to let slip. I only thing I would say is it does get very busy so I would highly recommend you book in advance to make sure you get a table. itsnosmallthing.weebly.c…

photos.caption: Photo of Mien Tay - London, United Kingdom

QzZkHNxX5OCMM_27-Qmesg.text: Delicious food and great service. We booked a table for 20 last minute on a Saturday night. We had one waitress for our whole table and she was very obliging.

gybpSy5WvvAnhNBlwShERA.text: I like Mien Tay.We passed by the near empty restaurant next door as we enter Mien Tay and I think "gosh they can't compete with Mien Tay". But I am wrong, its actually the overfloor section for Mien Tay... we go back out onto the street and enter. There are a rake of empty tables in the front half, but we are put down the back in the corner, squished in, surrounded by occupied tables. Odd really, but it amused me really.The staff are focused on serving quick and they don't really focus on the service with a smile tactic. Again something that amused me. And boy were they quick. All dishes were brought out in quicktime.We were visiting friends in London and this was their favourite Viet restaurant in the City, so we let them order and we shared everything.My highlights were the Octopus and Spring Rolls, as starters. For the mains I enjoyed the shredded duck, chicken curry and whole sea bass with ginger.There is an office licence two doors away from Mien Tay, it had a good selection of wine and beer, so get your BYOB here.I recommend Mien Tay, its was a bustling close up experience.

_q5ZLrASKnwIQvBqfGGOgw.text: The second star is because my pho was quite tasty and they had the accompanying plate of condiments/toppings that I've been missing from other restaurants. Otherwise the service was bad. They had a hard time taking down our orders despite seeing the menus for themselves and going sometimes by item number rather than what we said. Even still they forgot parts of peoples orders, especially the drinks part.I was at a ten top table for a birthday party and according to the birthday girl who reserved the table they started kicking us out of the space about 20 minutes before our allotted time was up. They were really trying to rush us out of there and even asked us to please leave at one point. I was about to say I'll try and come back here another time with a smaller group on a slower day but why bother? There's like five other vietnamese restaurants on the same friggin street. Thanks but no thanks Mien Tay.

yIUAB0eTrB5NpZuB-bmCdA.text: I want to give ths place 5 stars but even though the food is mouthwateringly good, the venue itself is not remarkable enough. That and I'm a tough cookie to please (ask the other half!!!).So if you are looking for good Vietnamese food in London, THIS is the place to come. The easily sat a large group of Yelpers, 10 in total, had no problem with us bringing our own booze and charged us £8 a head to stuff our faces. The menu was endless, and like so many Vietnamese around here, resembled the Argos catalogue in size. Flicking though is eye opening with unusal seafood and frogs legs (which I tried) on the menu.Seriously, this place is new and I think it's going to fill the others with fear as they know what they are doing. Attentive staff, non greasy food and a HUGE selection. BYOB to top it all of and I'm starting to wonder why I haven't put this as 5 stars!?

photos.caption: Photo of Mien Tay - London, United Kingdom. from website

IXZwd0ZIIf0e-HAATiJLJQ.text: Like a lot of the other reviewers... I wish their level of tasty food matched their decor.  I understand the hole-in-the-wall decor, but there's a line. All the seating feels like they just bought it from a cheap patio sale. Wicker chairs are not comfortable to sit in for long periods of time, and even less comfortable to eat off of. Dusty fixtures and food stained walls are not appetizing to look at. But even besides all of that, I have to say that I've enjoyed everything I've had here. The food is fresh and tasty. But I don't recommend eating the garnish. It always look stale and old. Clearly it's just there for presentation. And at least there's no msg taste like in the place a few doors down....

xAKJSlhTlpDUGOMKtJU4EA.text: 7.30pm on  a Tuesday night and Mien Tay was packed. It was my first time here and I was pleasantly surprised by the atmosphere - if you're facing away from the road it truly does feel like you're in a restaurant somewhere in South East Asia!For £32 total, 2 of us enjoyed: fresh rolls, the most delicious crispy sweet corn spring rolls(!!!), a big bowl of vermicelli/tofu/lemongrass, a gingery duck dish, steamed rice, OJ, a hot Vietnamese coffee and a beer.Service was snappy and generally pretty nice. I'm not sure I'd come back here with a group or for a special occasion, but for a casual meal early week it was pretty good.

zotB1oOeouUBiCub9Ki4bQ.text: Really really good. The only vietnamese restaurant i go to in the area. My favs - beef salad, mixed bun xa bo, beef pho, fresh spring roll. Don't go there for 5 star service. There is a 30% chance the service won't be great (wrong dish, late dish, rushed staff etc.). For some reason the staff seem to be more efficient during dinner rush. Don't go there for the ambiance - it's not the best (bad lighting, strong smell at times, not too comfortable, risk of embarrassing cover playlists, etc)Go there for the food and it won't disappoint. Never disappointed me!And - great value.

bswsCTSkxeOjAxb_7g9Lww.text: I can't decide whether The Bodyguard soundtrack that was playing during my meal made the mediocre pho better or worse.Incidentally, RIP Whitney Houston.

xjCFvDxBptD18RFOjWKvig.text: Quick, tasty, affordable Vietnamese food. Whats not to like!? Service and facilities are unfussy and basic but if what your after is good quality, authentic cuisine then you are in the right place. Highly recommend the shredded beef pancake starters and I have yet to be disappointed in any main dish I have ordered. The classic Pho is a winner as are all there noodles and stir fry dishes. I would say best on the stretch - and there are a fair few to choose from. Go for the green sign!

DK8EXoaTdS0kRnKYbgVdig.text: The place where Chow Yun Fat adorns the window. It's packed nearly every evening with a queue out the door around 7-8pm.This place understands what customers are looking for. Good value and tasty food. Throwing in some extras like free prawn crackers to start and oranges (decoratively cut) at the end does no harm either!My favourite meal is the lunch menu Honey BBQ chicken with rice. It comes with a free vegetable soup, that tastes better than it should for that price. Plenty of veg and lots of egg, make this soup a perfect starter. Then the main, the honey glazed grilled pork is just charred to a tasty piece of perfect. Accompanied by some salad, rice and of course boiled rice. The rice is cooked here exactly as I like it. Not wet, nor too dry. Firm, and sticks to the chopsticks making for easy gripping. After that feast, you have of course the oranges chopped into segments with a toothpick, using the peel as a clever little bowl.If you're in the area on a weekday (which is the only time they do the lunch special I've just described, please get the Honey BBQ chicken. However I hear the Pho specials are good too. You just cannot go wrong here.

photos.caption: Photo of Mien Tay - London, United Kingdom. Vietnamese pancake (banh xeo)
Photo of Mien Tay - London, United Kingdom. Honey BBQ Chicken
Photo of Mien Tay - London, United Kingdom. Summer Rolls

fhvoDaG44My7pFZveSuGfw.text: One of the best Vietnamese in London. Its popularity increases every day and it is more and more difficult to get a table. Book if you can because it gets crowded. This place is ideal for vegetarians, look up for the first page of the menu and you will see a selection of "beef-like" "chicken-like" tofu. I recommend the "beef-like" one. I have not had such a good "bun" elsewhere. Also try the starter with tofu - it is very original and tasty. They bring an orange with the bill. Nice sweet taste before leaving ... full! You can ask for a tupperware if you don't manage to finish your food. You will be happy for lunch the next day I promise!

photos.caption: Photo of Mien Tay - London, United Kingdom

qhfXYcOh_PzxiWL7p1v17w.text: Glacial service and little basic manners.  Overcooked beef on the chow mein and bland tasting - perhaps the most bland tasting Vietnamese I've ever tasted.  Went through the entire meal without being brought so much as a drink of water.  Way overpriced for the schlock they're shovelling onto plates.   InCREDIBLE that this made a top 10 in TimeOut.

c7kENO2Y_0yqEAjGDerIzg.text: Along Kingsland Road you have lots of choice in Vietnamese restaurants, and if you are local, you can try all of them.. but as you will find, some are good for certain dishes, whereas others will make deep pho broth.. depends what you are looking for, and quite popular now (for us winos) BYOB is a nice addition - this place doesn't For starters, we had the salt, pepper and garlic squid - the batter was even and crispy upon bite. There was very little carrot and daikon pickle (which I love), instead there was plenty of randomly shredded cabbage and carrots. The stir-fried onions was nice but the almost-raw-crunchy ones were a bit much for a weekday lunchtime - like hey, I have the rest of my day and the lovely squid gets a bit ruined by this strong, pungent flavour.For main, I had the bo luc lac - shaking beef 'salad'. In this case, it was still pretty tasty but not as authentic. Tasted like they had used some chinese 5 spice mix, but my experience with that mix has always been good so the dish in front of me was tasty and with that similar depth. Admittedly, my dish is bo luc lac and different places cook and serve it differently, so hey I am a bit extra in terms of standards, authenticity and taste - but every foodie has their preferences, eh?Try it if you are local, as you can work your way through Kingsland Road, but don't travel here especially.. its a-ok !

dRbjsTiGTZkVqOX5ff16lg.text: You don't need to go to the West Ends ChinaTown for the infamous farcical rude service anymore - Visit trendy Hoxton and Mien Tay!I've been meaning to check this place out for some time now, but don't really come out to hipster land too often. But we were invited here as part of a friends birthday meal. There were a good group of us and we had to make sure we weren't more than 5 mins late of we'd loose our table! Upon arrival we were told 'You order now' when half of the table hadn't even sat in their seats. However, we got a couple of Vietnamese rolls, whole fish in chilli and beers for the table while everyone perused the menu. Another cute quirk to the place is the somewhat eerie scenes encased in the tables. Mini wells and dried out foliage trapped inside the glass made a great conversation piece with friends of friends you've never met. But overall the decore is modest and clean.Don't say Mien Tay doesn't give you choice, because oh boy do you get options. All 10 odd pages or so, which makes it just so much harder to decide! Eventually I opted for a mixed seafood in black bean sauce with egg fried rice (again, not particularly adventurous but I just couldn't decide in time!!). The food came out in what seemed like record timing. It was generous, fresh and really tasty.  The Spring rolls to start were equally as moreish and I would say a must when visiting. Everyone was making noises in appreciation and loosening their belts at the end of the meal. There were a modest selection of beers on offer, but wine was only served by the bottle - so get use to sharing. At the end of the meal, the bill came and I was amazed at the value. They must had knocked a few bits off the bill for us because we ended up with £20 per head inc drinks. Bargain. Despite trying (and we did) not one of the staff cracked a smile the whole evening and after the last plate was taken away we were asked to leave! I will definitely go back and choose something a bit more adventurous on the menu next time. It's just great value and great food brought to your table quickly and with a whole heap of attitude.

satHu5k6QusFKitgw2ezMg.text: Delicious food at a good price. Not as flashy as some other places nearby but we were very happy with our meal. The food was genuine  Vietnamese style. Will

_AY1E0lSr19N0l-hkoZz1g.text: DELICIOUS! Very impressed with this restaurant. Super fresh, nice presentation, and different more interesting than other Vietnamese restaurants that I've visited and enjoyed in the past. Highly recommend. Try the pancake thing! Interesting and delicious!

i_H-BJW7zGNj_yzbKaDkfw.text: My friend brought me here, it's quite popular, it was pretty packed when I got there last Saturday. I hate that the tables are all right next to each other, you are gonna be legit right next to your neighbor...The tables by the door is cold! Just when someone opens the door, the service is nice. The fresh rolls (shrimp and pork) was good, but smaller than what i'm used to at home. I got the sliced beef and beef ball pho.. It was fine, I guess this is good in london's eye. There are two floors, and upstairs was also filled. You might have to wait if you come a bit later...like around dinner time... The fried calamari i had was aite, could have been more flavorful. BYOB!! wooo.Good price for pho.

photos.caption: Photo of Mien Tay - London, United Kingdom. pho!
Photo of Mien Tay - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Mien Tay - London, United Kingdom. springroll

8h3oGoaOek0tDd8fLCSk0Q.text: Mien Tay is my favourite Vietnamese on Kingsland Road and you know they must be doing something right when they have two restaurants on the same road and both are almost always full! The reason this place gets five stars is the chargrilled goat which is not only a bit different but absolutely delicious. My boyfriend has tried the eel which is also delicious but we both agree the goat takes some beating. Starters include fresh rolls which are also really tasty. Its not a fancy restaurant and the food comes quickly. It might take a bit longer than you'd expect to get the staff's attention but that's because they are always so busy! Its delicious, inexpensive, honest food and the only place where I can get a G&T for £3-4.

O-urzH7lMKunzkli9A49zg.text: I made my way up Shoreditch to Kingsland to try Song Que per recommendation by a professor of mine. Upon entering Song Que, there was quite a queue to be seated, so I opted fow or the next most populous Vietnamese restaurant with available seating which turned out to be Mien Tay.I was promptly seated once I entered. After a through investigation of the menu, I narrowed down my selection to Pho, Bun Hue, and duck. I asked one of the servers what Bun Hue was, and she came out of the kitchen a minute later with a plate of the noodles; this gesture set the tone for the service. Anytime I looked up at a server, he or she immediately responded. Extremely attentive and helpful.I decided on a Bun Hue item entitled Spicy Vermicelli Soup with Beef. The portion was more than reasonable for £6.50. I added chili peppers, cilantro, a few very small basil-like leaves, and what my very limited vocabulary of Vietnamese vegetables calls sprouts. The flavors interacted perfectly. The lemon grass did not overpower the thinly cut beef. The chili peppers cleaned my sinuses right up.To cool down I ordered a rainbow drink which contained mung beans, gelatinous seaweed, and coconut milk; I did not consume it properly at first, so one of the waiters came over and showed me how to properly enjoy the drink. It was an excellent supplement to the dish. I was very pleased with my experience.

wT8WqkNPBMdx7XuXVDFo7g.text: Feel good food. My preferred choice amongst all of them on kingsland road. Quick, fresh and tasty. And: their vegetarian meat imitations are unbeaten! They have a special category on the menu (not just "Tofu"). Try the Pho with "beef" the "pork" and the "duck". Also when not (yet) a vegetarian! It's 2016, we are intelligent, know our habits are catastrophic and can act positively!

UHRpntjxcFRkvQm61i-WWA.text: This is a lovely place to go and have a great Vietnamese meal. It's cash only, but there's a shop a couple of doors away that you can get cash. We had seen the note in this weeks Time Out which mentioned the owners charitable work and their future expansion. The place was full by the time we left. The food is great. Service is a little brusque, but all in all a good experience. The fresh rolls are very good.

gHuIZMPgzfh_3Xs33B-mwg.text: Actually went to the Clapham Junction restaurant, was amazing as usual! The crispy pancake starter is tasty, as were the spring rolls (home made! Not the usual standard ones you get) the whole sea bass with lemon grass and chilli is absolutely divine!

photos.caption: Photo of Mien Tay - London, United Kingdom. Vietnamese Rainbow Drink

sH6fKUJyXEc6wsI4XXjUhQ.text: We came here for dinner the other night after reading some reviews online. Overall we were quite happy with the whole experience.We were seated as soon as we arrived. It is worth noting that there were two of us and we came here on a Monday night. As such, i don't know if this place gets crowded on weekends.Service was fairly quick and everything that we ordered was quite good. Also, we got a bottle of wine for just under 15 GBP which seems reasonable for London.The only downside is that the place is fairly small and you wind up sitting quite close to other guests.All in all, I very much enjoyed dining here and would definitely return.

lv0rYYfd5K7hKs_4rLVccw.text: If I didn't see their reviews, I would have completely missed it because it was in the same area as the famous Song Que and I would have just walked past it. It's not the nicest place, quite crumby honestly and the furniture looks run-down but the food is great and quite cheap. Love that you get free shrimp crackers to start :) We all got different phos for a Sunday lunch and their rolls are yummy. Would go back if I were in the area for something really chill and casual.

photos.caption: Photo of Mien Tay - London, United Kingdom

gi-igTJO1Nl0fA7qW10KFQ.text: Once was enough for me here.I've been to all of the Vietnamese restaurants on Kingsland Road, some many times, and my experience here was definitely the worst.I work in the area, so came for lunch.  We were a small group, and the restaurant was almost empty.  Despite this, it took well over an hour to bring the food (at lunchtime). We asked a few times, and the staff reacted in a grumpy manner.  When it finally came, it was below the standard of the other restaurants in the area.I may have given two stars, as I've had worse food, but the final star is lost for the level of hygiene.  You see, our office overlooks the kitchen at the back.  Regularly we see them washing pots in the street, and you really don't want to be there when they take the bins out.  All I'll say is that prawns should definitely be disposed of in a more timely fashion!

gvP6hQlmptlP8ZHeFV22BA.text: There's a lot of competition on Kingsland Road but for me it's one of the best Vietnamese in the area. I've eaten here several times and it's always great. I also love the little scenes inside the tables. Portions are huge!

photos.caption: Photo of Mien Tay - London, United Kingdom. One of the fish dishes with mango.  Phenomenal portion and value. Yum!

k7niGtXR4FIqe1wOHo6rBg.text: Walked by here on a stroll through Hoxton and decided to check the reviews on yelp before trying it. Brought my boyfriend as he had been craving for some good pho like we used to have as students in Vancouver, BC. We had some pretty high expectations (based on reviews and photos) plus we are kind of particular about our pho. My review is mainly concerned with the service we experienced, the pho turned out to be excellent.We went on a weekday at 4:30 before the dinner rush. I ordered the chicken and he ordered the beef brisket. The first thing I noticed was no matter what meat you chose, the broth is always beef. I'm not sure if other places do this but the restaurant I used to frequent in Vancouver made my chicken pho with chicken broth. The food came and to my surprise, we were served two bowls of beef. Additionally, the beef one brought to my boyfriend was not the type of beef he ordered. Just as we were about to say something a man and our server come over to our table. I mentioned the situation and I think they gave us a rushed apology but what I clearly is feeling like they barely acknowledged us and just treated us like we weren't there while they talked to themselves about the problem. The bowls were taken away, as well as the plate with the garnishes, and eventually replaced with what we actually ordered. Then they replaced the garnish plate with a different garnish plate and I was a bit disappointed since the new did not have as much basil. I don't really see the necessity to replace it when we didn't even touch it. I never found out what happened exactly but I guess there was a bit of a mix up in the kitchen. Since the pho was very good and I live close by, I would be willing to come back and try here again and hope this experience was just a one time accident!

4PHzeWMaJdaiSgedO6JOkA.text: Another good Vietnamese choice!We really enjoyed Mien Tay. We especially liked the fried spring rolls. They were a unique preparation we had not seen before. I enjoyed it!

zpqCuazJVPYc6D1njTgvZg.text: The food here never fails to live up to expectations. From the outside it is very unassuming and doesn't stand out on a street full of Vietnamese. It's worth finding it though and there may even be a queue but the food is worth it.  They have an extensive, authentic menu and it's all reasonably priced. This place used to be BYOB but now they've got their license there's a selection of beers to choose from. This is definitely one of the better places to eat on the Pho mile

cPHfguale_UIB-2ypa1VLA.text: Fantastic Vietnamese and the atmosphere after 8pm is wicked. Love it here. I used to come here many years ago with an ex-friend and it was always a place we ended up after a few drinks staying until gone 1am. It's a BYO which not only makes it cheap but also makes a brilliant atmosphere. If your in London and staying in central London defiantly come here for some late nights get chow and live like a local.

Ur8tsSZvR97514k8Sp72vg.text: Food was not good and the waiter was a dick head! My wife and I spent 18 pounds and waited in an hour of traffic just to get to this place and as we arrived we were met with a lot of hostility it seemed like the waiter didn't want to serve us he seemed annoyed and impatient. I could tell when my wife ordered banh xeo and asked to have chicken and shrimp but he kept telling us no only chicken or porkprown. I kept thinking wtf is porkprown but what he was saying was pork and prawns he was just saying it so fast we couldn't hear him. So instead he let out a big sigh and said pork and prawns like picture!! And we said ok let's get that. Biggest mistake the banh xeo was terrible flavorless . And the pho the pho is just as bad Avoid going here the place is a front for shit food and even shittier customer service don't be fooled by photos of Gordon and Benedict they're all a tie to fool you into eating here. If only Gordon had a taste of their shitty foods he'd flip out!!

a5IHej84nwKdP9SkFS4Bbw.text: - personable staff- one dimensional broth left something to be desired, decent but missing a lot of the fragrant notes/flavor that you'd normally expect from pho (star anise, etc) - very broad noodles (almost like chinese ho fun)- viet iced coffee was extremely sweet, the espresso flavor seemed to be an afterthought- reasonable pricing for the area but more expensive than NYC

xTowLgG3flU_ahgvHmOyeA.text: Pretty good Vietnamese food in a cluster of Vietnamese restaurants in Shoreditch.  The porkchop with lemongrass was tender and I liked how they sliced the meat.  The pho was not so great -- the broth was a bit bland and lacked depth.  Still it was nice to have more textures and flavors after a bit too much soft and bland British food.

B8anvwEvPyyGXo-zveHkLg.text: Had to ask five times for tap water. They forgot my food order. Food was overwhelmed with spice.

GNaI2O1HfaBLjat5IkRuKw.text: Amongst all the Vietnamese restaurants in London, Mien Tay is my ultimate favourite. The broth of the chicken pho here is spot on, incredibly tasty and they are not shy with the ingredients. Highly recommend the bo la lot (grilled minced beef wrapped in betel leaf) as its just amazing. We also asked for extra lettuce and herbs for this dish, and they happily obliged. Their fried whole sea bream with green mango is also a winner. Definitely a favourite dish here. Their bo tai chan (raw beef salad) is also a favourite. Taste is great, portion is very good and still leaves you wanting more. Decor and ambiance feels very homey, overall a very good restaurant and highly recommend if you'd like to eat authentic Vietnamese food. Very reasonably priced too!

photos.caption: Photo of Mien Tay - London, United Kingdom. Bo tai chan (raw beef salad with citrus dressing)
Photo of Mien Tay - London, United Kingdom. Bo la lot (grilled minced beef wrapped in betel leaf)

0WkRS6wu4dLob7trwivfUg.text: My favorite of the 3 Vietnamese places we've tried on Kingsland...so far.While the pho I've had at PPQ and Kevin's in San Francisco are more spiced and herbal, Mien Tay's was cleaner, clearer, but no less flavorful. It just played more on sour than spices.The showstopper, however, was the fried Sea Bream with Mango. It's a weird choice to flavor a very fresh fish with fermented fish sauce, but it worked. The mango may have been too bland to eat plain, but created a refreshing, tender slaw. And the fish was perfectly fried - the meat was still tender and moist, but most of the bones were fried enough to be crunchy additions instead of painful detractors. There were hardly any bones left when we were done with it.Also, I'm a sucker for a complimentary basket of Shrimp Chips and sliced orange to finish.

photos.caption: Photo of Mien Tay - London, United Kingdom. All that was left after we devoured the Sea Bream with Mango - crunchy fried tail, jaw, fins & all.

leuGmgD3onsb9C3Mzy9JXw.text: Well, I wondered what all the hype was all about saying this is the best pho in town.  I thought it was just OK.  I think our American cousin does it better.  The broth here did not provide the punch that I was hoping for.  It was normal broth.  There was nothing to shout about.  I have tried a few in London but Mian Tay is up there but not really 'up' there compared to the real deal.  I am still waiting for a Vietnamese restaurant to wow me with the same one that I have eaten in Vietnam.  The Vietnamese community here needs to do better.  We probably do not have a big enough Vietnamese community to justify for really good pho.  That said, let's wait and see what others can do.  Still on my to do list to search for the best pho.  Portion size was big enough.  I thought they should provide more free garnish like sprouts, mints and lime on the table like how they do in Vietnam and America. We lack of that it seems in London.  Spring rolls was good as well and again nothing great to shout about.  Would not mind coming back but I think I'll rather go to a new Vietnamese establishment to search for the best pho.

photos.caption: Photo of Mien Tay - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Mien Tay - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Mien Tay - London, United Kingdom

1HNRCqcoa7sUiMLFPF3vAg.text: New Yorkers: believe me when I tell you that Mien Tay is the same level as our own Pho Bang in Flushing, Queens. This restaurant not only has fantastic food, but lovable staff as well. I ordered number 141 on the menu, which was Vermicelli noodles with char grilled pork and spring rolls. The pork was tender and char grilled to perfection, and the spring rolls were crunchy and packed with delicious vegetables and meat. The mint, parsley, basil, lettuce, carrots and cucumbers were superbly crunchy. The noodles were springy and not overly cooked to mushiness. The fish sauce was sweet and tangy as it should always be. The textures and aromas of this delightful bowl were fresh and pleasing. This was perhaps the most delicious Vietnamese meal I have ever eaten in London. As for the staff, firstly I found that the waiters were somewhat brusque and unresponsive, making me and my party wait for half the time for tap water. This was a bit annoying, but we figured that we didn't need it right away. However. What saved the day was the friendly Vietnamese-Polish waiter who gave us our water happily and carried on a lively conversation about his home country and the languages that we both spoke. Overall, Mien Tay is a wonderful restaurant that makes you feel at home with its fantastic food and smiling staff.

-MZTvll5iazhWEiVj0qQ6A.text: This is a lovely and tasty Vietnamese restaurant at Kingsland road. After reading the reviews, I make a right choice to try there. We ordered a few dishes which is recommended by the friendly staff. The signature dish would be mango Seabass, it is .highly recommended. It does not disappointed us although it seem to be a busy night in the restaurant. We would go and revisit again.

photos.caption: Photo of Mien Tay - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Mien Tay - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Mien Tay - London, United Kingdom

pOf4cY8c6xHcQFc9d6YSjA.text: Came here for a quick midweek lunch. They have a separate express lunch menu which is incredibly cheap, most expensive dish £7.50, which also comes with complimentary jasmine tea.I ended up going for the Brisket Pho. The stock packed so much flavour and the quality of the ingredients showed. I was tempted to get a starter of some sort and glad I didn't, as the main dish itself was extremely generous and I wouldn't have be able to eat anything more.100% worth a visit and good to try at lunch when it isn't as busy. (Visit - Lunch 02/02/2016)

photos.caption: Photo of Mien Tay - London, United Kingdom. Lunch beef pho special.

BDS7qV9BZkScECg1TBCBrQ.text: I have only had the sweet and sour seafood soup because I wasn't particularly hungry. Good broth and fair quantity of seafood for the price (£ 6.5). You get complementary shrimp cracker in the beginning and fresh orange in the end which is quite appreciable. Smiling and friendly waiters.

Um_L6E9Khc2fcGG0nq0n_g.text: The food is always great here. Service is hit or miss. I just spent an hour fifteen in here, a large chunk of that time I was the only customer in the restaurant. Eating took 15-20 mins of that time, the rest was me waiting, waiting to give my order and at least half an hour waiting for my bill after my plate was taken away....But the food is great.

SlMIVQ7dZC0VHjuklqQVtw.text: With a small shopfront and windows plastered with adverts and stickers, from the outside it is hard to gauge what lies instore inside Mien Tay. But upon entering you come to realise that the restaurant is atmospheric and quirky, authentically Vietnamese and offers a good variety of menu options. The inside of the menu even includes a warm welcoming message from Mr Su Tran and Mrs My Le. In this message they have a mission statement to provide fresh and fragrant cooking and indeed this was reflected in what I was served with. The pancake starter was a golden brown and crispy as it should be and the vegetables where crunchy-fresh. The fish sauce and soup base for the noodles were also pleasantly fragrant. Even the after-meal free oranges were nicely cut into pieces. The flowering tea is a nice touch to have available on the menu but be warned that the teapot is poorly designed as it allows a substantial amount of tea to trickle from the spout. The service was also a little off as the waiter is charming enough when taking orders but then takes your plate or bowl away far too quickly - basically when you have just taken your last bite he will pounce. Meanwhile the toilets have so much graffiti and stickers on display that it it looks as though they have let it get out of hand to avoid cleaning it up and in the hope that it appears creative. There is a mop in the toilet and an upstairs seating area that looked desolate and unused. So overall the aesthetics may need a little polishing but the food and drink here is true to form and genuinely good quality Vietnamese.

photos.caption: Photo of Mien Tay - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Mien Tay - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Mien Tay - London, United Kingdom

OiCIxfTjBxRCpJEtgyRzzg.text: I've eaten at many of the Vietnamese restaurants on Kingsland Road and this has to be one of the top 3 or so. The staff were very friendly, the portion sizes amazingly generous and the food fresh and flavorful. I would certainly come here again and recommend it to friends looking for a great Pho, crunchy pancake or fresh spring rolls!

photos.caption: Photo of Mien Tay - London, United Kingdom. Sliced beer Pho to finish
Photo of Mien Tay - London, United Kingdom. Giant Crispy Pancake!
Photo of Mien Tay - London, United Kingdom. Garlic squid!

0Iz9qJKa5AS3vsl77kRZSQ.text: Not the cheapest place to get Vietnamese, and the service isn't the best but the food makes this place worth a trip. The spring rolls are beautifully crisp with a delicious filling of moist pork and prawn and come with a generous amount mint and coriander (they could do with more lettuce, but I find this with most Vietnamese places).The pho is light and fragrant with a great flavour. We also went for the crispy sea bream with mango and fish sauce which was cooked well - crispy skin with succulent flesh that just flakes away from the bone.

Q2ik3gyZA4JVt7e3DodiAg.text: I heard so much about this place and I wanted to try it for a long time. We went there on a Thursday night and it was quite full. We had to queue outside for 15 minutes. Finally we got a table (not a really good one, next to the door) and we ordered a couple of dishes. We asked the waitress for their specialities but she wasn't really nice or helpful. The food was OK. Not a big deal really. Spring rolls as a started and chicken curry with rice for me. I was so hungry that I couldn't tell if the food was excellent (as it said in the front door of the restaurant), but I'm sure it's not the best I try. A little to much greasy I would said.The price is not too bad. You can have dinner for two for less than £20. But don't expect anything fancy or elegant. Typical Kingsland Road Vietnamese Restaurant.I think I'll give them a second chance, just in case!

photos.caption: Photo of Mien Tay - London, United Kingdom. Vegetable spring rolls and Spicy chicken
Photo of Mien Tay - London, United Kingdom. Salt & pepper fried squid
Photo of Mien Tay - London, United Kingdom. Table!

RvvwdyU2Vd7NjwxZeYeX3Q.text: We really wanted a Vietnamese meal on our trip to Shoreditch and couldn't decide between the many options, so went here purely on Yelp reviews - and I'm glad we did! The prawn curry clay pot was unreal - full of flavour, spicy, and lots of protein. The egg fried rice was some of the best we've eaten. The service was exceptionally quick, especially considering how packed it was - there was a queue out the door at one point, on a Sunday... Excellent value, the whole bill coming to less than £30. Highly recommended!

3tDUIFGF9wCVssOyOjn0OQ.text: Food was horrible. The pho wasn't aromatic but rather plain and putrid. The tea wasn't minty. The food lacked spice, pepper, salt...The pho xao was inexperienced. It was far too moist, wet and wasn't even "fried", more like boiled and then flash fried. One of the male staff, wearing green, had the horrible customer service attitude, he was not attentive and often avoid eye contact, he wasn't enjoying his job - I get that. He expressed it so obvious and hard it was actually very uncomfortable. The stars given to other friendly staff, the female and male who attended to our needs kindly. The meat tasted good, nice marinade.

gUQsKgvRevupT3xU4Jwj5A.text: YES. Best pho I have had in Europe! As a visitor from a California, which has a larger selection of authentic Vietnamese restaurants, I was really missing pho ga that had savory broth and flavorful chicken. This restaurant was delivered from the heavens.I don't think that my boyfriend and I even talked to each other during the meal - That's how quickly and enthusiastically we were eating! And free shrimp crackers on the table as a starter? Now that's 5 stars.

photos.caption: Photo of Mien Tay - London, United Kingdom. Pho ga!

QTliV9FTy1pT_TXCSB4bkg.text: Came here for lunch on a Tuesday and it was completely empty, which usually turns me off, but reading all the reviews I told myself it would still be good, and I was right!  The free prawn crackers are a treat to start and my chicken pho was delightful.  Service was quick (once it took them 5 minutes to realize we were in the restaurant wanting to order) and the waiter was kind enough to tell me that I don't need the basil stems in my broth, just the leaves (such a rookie).  Standard prices for good tasty portions.

QqpeXG66cvdtA1tjaW9JxQ.text: Update I've returned to Mein Tay several times since my initial visit. While the food was always good when I visited, a friend of mine (who also loves Mein Tay) once took a few people there for lunch and said that not only was the food horrid, they managed to forget one dish even though they were the only guests at that time. And apparently the Vietnamese coffee they served was 90% condensed milk and 10% coffee. When I went there a few weeks ago, I ordered Prawn & Pork summer rolls. After eating a bit I realised that they were pork-less. I complained and first I was told that the waitress had misunderstood my order. When I asked to have the dish replaced the story was suddenly changed and I was told that the kitchen did not have any pork for the rolls. Although they brought me a pot of tea to compensate, I would have preferred to a) be notified that they were unable to serve me the ordered dish, instead of serving something different and hoping that I would not notice, or b) either replace the item or take it off my bill when I did notice. During the same visit a guy came in to tell the manager that they had charged his card twice for the same meal. After some hemming and hawing, they finally agreed that he could come round and have some food on the house, i.e. they were not willing to give him his money back. Having said all that, I still think that Mein Tay is one of the better Vietnamese restaurants in Shoreditch but I'm concerned that they are starting to go downhill as a result of their success. The lunch disaster indicates that they may have badly trained cooks in the kitchen during lunch. Their refusal to react appropriately to mistakes they made, i.e. overcharging customers or serving the wrong dishes, may fall back on them one day. I certainly hope not; watch this space for further updates. ##################### There is nothing to fault about this place. We had several starters, of which the superb summer rolls deserve an honourable mention. As a main course I had a lovely hot and sour Vietnamese fish soup. It was a huge portion but so good that I finished it off. We then ordered Vietnamese coffee and the super-lovely owner (previously metioned in other reviews), after hearing about my friend's trip to Vietnam, brought us a tea on the house after the coffee because 'in Vietnam they drink some tea after the coffee' - a very kind and sweet gesture.All of this combined with the huge portions and byo add up to the Mien Tay being my favourite Vietnamese in London, I'll be back for more!

AP1hzrm1DNB5ahHGFgE5hw.text: This vietnamese gem is amazing! Fantastic food with great staff and BYO... all good!The food here is fantastic - we normally order a load of dishes to share and this works so well as you get to taste loads of lovely food. The squid, the pork, the fish dishes.. try them all, they are amazing.. go there soon!

jmzZhEtq5gOmDwHKuBg8rw.text: I'm no expert on Vietnamese food, but Mien Tay efficiently and easily catered to our party of 7. The food was generally pretty good, especially considering most main dishes are around the 6-7 pound mark. I'd recommend the duck with cashew nuts. Fresh rolls to start with went down well too. They have a license but you can also bring your own, although it's wise to bring a bottle opener, because it can take a minute or two to get that cold beer opened up for your drinking pleasure.

GVB_M4QCR5R68MWvi5LP0Q.text: As you walk down Shoreditch high street deeper into the north, towards the dark interiors of Hackney, you come to a point where you find that the street is lined with cheap Vietnamese restaurants on both sides, as far as one can see.Mien Tay is far from being a special occasion place. Its small ... its cramped ... it pretty much stretches my mental definition of a restaurant (as opposed to a take-away joint). But it serves very good and extremely cheap food. I am not qualified to judge how authentic the preparations were, but they were good enough for me not to care :)We were there in a big group of eight ... so we ordered a lot of stuff ... from egg fried rice to pho ... and shared. But the reason why i will remember this restaurant forever is that this is the first place where i had frog (or to be more precise, frog legs). They seemed to me to be quite like chicken leg pieces ... just substantially thinner.Mien Tay allows you to bring your own alcohol ... and given that its located right next to an off license shop, we could finish off 2 bottles of hastily purchased wine. After having a full and enjoyable meal, another surprise was in store for us ... the bill was only about £10/person. It doesn't get any better, does it ?If you are looking for good, but not high-end, vietnamese food, then i highly recommend Mien Tay.

s2S-IwFucw1JFv9blXpdkQ.text: Happy Birthday to me!I decided it would be easiest for my birthday if I just had everyone meet at a restaurant.  My friend Jerry (who has a personal mission to find the best Pho in London) suggested this place.  He said it was possible the 2nd best Pho place in London AND it's BYOB, I thought, how can I go wrong with this place?So I sent out invites and booked the table.  I have to say, with all the hype from my friends, I was a little disappointed by this place.  Don't get me wrong, it was delicious and all my friends enjoyed it very much.  But for me, the broth was too sweet in the Pho.So here is my recommendation, if you hungry for some good Vietnamese food, it's dinner time, you haven't made reservation for Song Que and your just too hungry to wait 45 minutes for a table there, then walk on down (half a block) to Mein Tay and grab your bite.  I would say it is the 2nd best place to eat on that strip.Oh, and for your Londoners (since I heard you don't use the term BYOB) it stands for Bring Your Own Booze.  Surely you have heard of this on American TV or movies though, right?

DtQmmASRJqCHrraek6M5rA.text: Excellent place for pho, bun, and spring rolls. Quite similar to Vietnamese restaurants in San Diego, which was comforting and is a compliment. I think the flavors could have been a little stronger, but the food is fresh and tasty.

fe2gI4oqFnn5x8LA621HGw.text: Was slightly disappointed, it wasn't bad, but I'd heard good things and found it to be pretty average, maybe I ordered the wrong things (I don't remember what now, sorry!), but I found it a bit bland. Green Papaya on Mare St is my favourite that I've tried so far.

HdKpYYZ1dJnPm6YgnuWhog.text: Without a doubt, THE BEST vietnamese on Kingsland Road. Nay, London. Nay, England! ok ok you get my drift.. In a sea of vietnamese restaurants, this is my shining light. Every week it seems a new restaurant opens up or closes down on Kingsland rd, I often consider writing a review of each one but I get as far as Mien Tay and I know, there's no need. K I might go on a bit, but it's worth it. This place used to be Thang Loi, which we loved. Yum. then one day pooof our favourite restaurant was called something else..untrusting but hungry we ventured in..the staff were a pleasure and helped us come to terms with the new menu which to my shock, no longer had my favourite dish on it (ca cha la vong). Not to be outdone, the owner rushed off and instructed the chef to make us the dish..and it was lovely! That gesture had me hooked..so we asked for recommendations. I'm telling you, you have to try the following: Salt chilli squid. It's too good! And, no lie, it was overheard that Chow Yun-Fat himself said it was the best he's ever had. Their version of summer rolls..exquisite! So fresh, the prawns..the mint.. Fish with mango and fish sauce..I was a bit dubious at first, but holy moly! Taste sensation! sizzling goat with galangal, try it! it's so good! I guess the best thing about Mien Tay is that the prices are as awesome as the food. It's incredibly cheap and is BYO so expect a shock when you get the bill! seriously, one of the tastiest meals you'll get in london and for about £15..

GZZ15YzdSORbzxc7drpMLA.text: Pork, shrimp wrap, mango source with fried fish, grill pork , beef pho recommended.

TsCkh7uSQwvWrA_sj3hXaw.text: Quality Vietnamese up in Lil Hanoi; it aint often I don't finish what's in front of me (a result of country upbringing methinks) and it felt criminal given the quality fare on offer. You won't be disappointed!

tX0KaZmbUeFj6K9NXWFs-A.text: Good food with reasonable prices. (Main dishes around 7,-) Small place with quick but polite service. BYO alcohol! Friday night was crowded but we got a table after 5 minutes. I can really recommend the won ton soup and the stir fried duck with bamboo shoots and chargrilled chicken with lemon leaf!

ETDBjhJAAZRAqlcudTq9dw.text: I totally agree with AnimalGirl - and can recount a very similar story! Living close by Thang Loi was our local and then one day we realised our fave dish (rabbit with honey) was not on the menu. We asked how long they had been open and it was about 4 weeks old. We tried the food and were blown away. The long long menu has so many amazing dishes on it it is so difficult to cut down when ordering. Highlights have to be salt and pepper squid, pork with honey and spices, seafood hot pot (def one for a group of friends), sizzling goat with galangal, frog's legs, beef salad, basically you could close your eyes, point at the menu and never be disappointed. I'm so tired of ordering I tend to ask the chef to make whatever he likes for us! Price is ridiculous, leave stuffed AND happy for about £15! Unheard of in London. I can't recommend it highly enough. If you have a favourite Vietnamese on Kingsland Road give it a miss just once and try Mien Tay.

CFrpfMXRkcFfXdBjXIgL5A.text: Have tried most of the Vietnamese restaurants in this area and finally got around to the Mien Tay restaurant, which was highly recommended by Time Out. I don't know why, it was truly awful. The restaurant has expanded into the shop next door, which is where they asked us to sit. Unfortunately the decoration is still unfinished, so it felt as if we were sitting in a building site. It was cold as well. The service wasn't good: they tried to rush us, and completely forgot about the squid starter. The food itself was terrible: the ribs were mostly fat, the squid (when it arrived) was bland, the chicken dish was mostly onions. the rice was broken up into many little pieces (so seemed more like cous-cous), and the shaking beef wasn't shaking at all, it had no life or flavour to it whatsoever. The portions of all of them were on the mean side (probably a good thing in retrospect). Visiting a restaurant is not just about the food, it is about the whole experience: the ambience of the place, the service, and about how comfortable the diner feels. This particular experience left a very nasty taste in the mouth: both literally and figuratively. The disappointment and feeling of being ripped-off was very strong. Based on this visit, one wonders how this place attracts customers at all.
